QUESTIONS: 1. What is the primary title of DepEd Order No. 13, s. 2017?
B: Policy and Guidelines on Healthy Food and Beverage Choices in Schools and in DepEd Offices
C: Revised Implementing Guidelines on the Operation and Management of School Canteens
DESCRIPTION A: Refers to general feeding programs, not the specific choices policy.
DESCRIPTION B: This is the exact official title as stated in the Department Order.
DESCRIPTION C: This refers to an older 2007 order that this policy modifies.
DECRIPTION D: This is a general description and not the legal title of the issuance.

QUESTIONS: 2. Which category of food is separated from the medium of immediate growth (soil, plant, or water) without any processing?
DESCRIPTION A: Processed foods have undergone sequences of events to improve quality.
DESCRIPTION B: Formulated foods are created by mixing different ingredients into a specific recipe.
DESCRIPTION C: "Minimalist" is not a standard technical classification for raw harvested food.
DECRIPTION D: Defined as items separated from growth medium without processing.

QUESTIONS: 3. Chemically, what is the most abundant component found in most foods?
DESCRIPTION A: Water typically dominates the weight of fresh produce and meats.
DESCRIPTION B: Minerals are present in relatively small proportions.
DESCRIPTION C: Carbohydrates are a main component, but water typically dominates.
DECRIPTION D: Lipids (fats) are major components but usually second to water or carbohydrates.

QUESTIONS: 4. What is the main benefit of food processing regarding food security?
A: It makes food completely free of all chemical residues.
B: It eliminates the need for any packaging materials.
C: It makes food available, safe, and wholesome over time.
D: It guarantees that all foods will have the same nutritional value.
DESCRIPTION A: Processing cannot always eliminate all residues like pesticides.
DESCRIPTION B: Processing usually requires more packaging to maintain the preserved state.
DESCRIPTION C: Vital for food security by ensuring safety and availability over time.
DECRIPTION D: Nutritional value changes based on the type of processing method used.

QUESTIONS: 5. Which of these is considered a "supplement" rather than a standard "food"?
B: A vitamin tablet consumed as a dosage
C: A fresh apple from an orchard
DESCRIPTION A: This is a processed fresh food.
DESCRIPTION B: Consumed as dosage mainly for health/disease prevention.
DESCRIPTION C: This is a fresh raw food.

QUESTIONS: 6. At what water activity level does microbial growth generally cease for most organisms?
DESCRIPTION A: No growth usually occurs below this level.
DESCRIPTION B: Many bacteria and molds grow easily at 0.90.
DESCRIPTION C: This is pure water; microbes thrive here.
DECRIPTION D: At 0.10, the food is extremely dry and stable against microbes.

QUESTIONS: 7. Which type of bound water is defined as "nonfreezing, strongly bound, and non-solvent"?
DESCRIPTION A: Type II is nonfreezing but "weakly bound solvent".
DESCRIPTION B: Type III is "limited freezing and loosely bound solvent".
DESCRIPTION C: Most models only classify three types of bound water.
DECRIPTION D: Defined as nonfreezing, strongly bound, and non-solvent.

QUESTIONS: 8. According to the Grover Model, which solute has the highest water-activity-depressing power (highest beta)?
DESCRIPTION C: Salt is most effective at lowering water activity.
DECRIPTION D: Fat has a beta of 0.0, meaning it does not depress water activity.

QUESTIONS: 9. Which process in frozen foods involves the migration and growth of ice crystals during storage?
DESCRIPTION A: Process where ice crystals ripen or coalesce.
DESCRIPTION B: Denaturation refers to the unfolding of proteins.
DESCRIPTION C: Retrogradation refers specifically to starch crystallization.
DECRIPTION D: Sublimation is the transition of ice directly to vapor.

QUESTIONS: 10. What is the primary cause of "staling" in baked goods during frozen storage?
DESCRIPTION B: Principal cause of staling in frozen baked goods.
DESCRIPTION C: Salt is an ingredient, not the cause of staling.

QUESTIONS: 11. Why is "quick freezing" generally preferred over "slow freezing"?
A: It creates large ice crystals that puncture cell walls.
B: It ensures the food tastes more salty.
C: It allows the food to be stored at room temperature.
D: It forms small ice crystals, reducing structural damage.
DESCRIPTION A: This is a disadvantage of slow freezing.
DESCRIPTION B: Freezing speed doesn't change salt content.
DESCRIPTION C: All frozen food must remain in the freezer.
DECRIPTION D: Forms small crystals, reducing structural damage.

QUESTIONS: 12. Rehydration of dried foods is technically described as:
A: A perfectly reversible process to dehydration.
B: The process of removing all water.
C: Usually irreversible due to structural changes during drying.
D: A way to increase the vitamin C content.
DESCRIPTION A: In practice, drying causes changes that cannot be perfectly undone.
DESCRIPTION C: Most changes during drying are irreversible.

QUESTIONS: 13. Which drying method involves the sublimation of ice directly into vapor?
DESCRIPTION A: Involves freezing and then subliming ice.
DESCRIPTION B: Uses heat to evaporate liquid water.
DESCRIPTION C: Uses heat to evaporate liquid water.
DECRIPTION D: Uses heat to evaporate liquid water.

QUESTIONS: 14. Nitrites are commonly used in meat preservation to prevent the growth of:
DESCRIPTION C: Specific inhibitor for botulism spores in meat.

QUESTIONS: 15. Which natural antioxidant is frequently used to enhance the stability of meat products?
DESCRIPTION A: This is a carbohydrate, not a primary antioxidant.

QUESTIONS: 16. What is the main purpose of "blanching" vegetables before freezing?
A: To cook them so they are ready to eat.
C: To make the vegetables change color to brown.
D: To inactivate enzymes that cause quality loss.
DESCRIPTION A: It is a pretreatment, not full cooking.
DESCRIPTION C: Blanching usually fixes the green color.
DECRIPTION D: Kills enzymes that cause off-flavors or color changes.

QUESTIONS: 17. Pasteurization differs from sterilization in that pasteurization:
B: It is only used for solid foods.
C: Uses lower temperatures to kill pathogens but not all spoilage organisms
DESCRIPTION C: Milder heat treatment designed for safety and quality.

QUESTIONS: 18. What does HACCP stand for?
A: Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Point
C: Healthy Apple and Carrot Canning Process
D: High Analysis of Chemical Contamination Points
DESCRIPTION A: Official name for the food safety system.
DESCRIPTION B: Temperature control is only a part of the system.
DESCRIPTION C: Incorrect expansion that narrows the scope.
DECRIPTION D: Too narrow and uses incorrect terminology.

QUESTIONS: 19. In HACCP, what is a "Critical Control Point" (CCP)?
A: The point where the food tastes the best.
B: A step where a hazard can be prevented, eliminated, or reduced to safe levels.
DESCRIPTION A: This is Quality Control, not Safety Control.
DESCRIPTION B: Specific stage where hazards are controlled.
DESCRIPTION C: CCP refers to function, not necessarily the end of the line.

QUESTIONS: 20. Which of the following is considered a "chemical hazard" in raw food materials?
21. Which vitamin is most likely to be destroyed during high-heat drying?
DESCRIPTION A: Most unstable vitamin and sensitive to heat.
DECRIPTION D: Generally stable to heat and processing.

QUESTIONS: 22. Which of the following is the primary preservative mechanism by which LAB inhibits the growth of competing microorganisms?
A: Increasing the temperature of the food matrix.
B: Removal of all moisture from the food.
C: Production of organic acids (mainly lactic acid) to lower the pH.
D: Creation of a physical barrier on the food surface.
DESCRIPTION A: Fermentation doesn't generate enough heat for preservation.
DESCRIPTION B: This is the mechanism of drying.
DESCRIPTION C: Primary mechanism is pH lowering via acids.

QUESTIONS: 23. Which physical state of food powder is most susceptible to stickiness and caking during storage?
DESCRIPTION C: Freezing can prevent caking but isn't a standard storage state.
DECRIPTION D: Amorphous states are prone to flow and stickiness.

QUESTIONS: 24. What is the "Critical Temperature" in the context of powder stickiness?
B: The temperature where the surface becomes sticky, often related to glass transition.
C: The temperature at which the food catches fire.
DESCRIPTION A: Not the point defining powder stickiness.
DESCRIPTION B: Critical threshold where rubbery particles bond.

QUESTIONS: 25. Caking of a powder is best defined as:
A: Turning a powder into a liquid.
B: Adding sugar to make a cake.
C: The formation of permanent clumps or a solid mass from a free-flowing powder.
D: The process of grinding large pieces into fine powder.

QUESTIONS: 26. What happens during "Solid Bridge" formation in caking?
A: Dissolved solutes (like sugar) crystallize or solidify at the contact points.
B: Particles are connected by a layer of ice.
C: The packaging material melts onto the food.
D: High-frequency sound waves fuse the powder.
DESCRIPTION A: Mechanism where solutes crystallize at contact points.
DESCRIPTION B: Ice bridges occur in frozen foods.

QUESTIONS: 27. Which common fodd additive is used to prevent caking?
DECRIPTION D: Designed specifically to keep powders free-flowing.

QUESTIONS: 28. Deliquescene is an extreme form of caking where:
A: The powder turns into a gas.
B: The powder absorbs so much moisture that it dissolves into a liquid solution.
DESCRIPTION B: Phase change to liquid due to high humidity.
DECRIPTION D: Browning may occur, but isn't the definition.

QUESTIONS: 29. How does "Mechanical Interlocking" contribute to stickiness?
A: By particles with irregular shapes physically tangling with each other.
C: By adding glue to the powder.
D: By the weight of the powder.
DESCRIPTION B: Not a mechanism in food powders.
DESCRIPTION C: No glue is added in this mechanism.

QUESTIONS: 30. Why does Consolidation caking happen at the bottom of a large storage?
B: Due to the static pressure (weight) of the powder above.
C: Because it is darker at the bottom.
D: Because the bottom is always wet.
DESCRIPTION C: Light does not affect physical pressure.
DECRIPTION D: Moisture worsens it, but pressure is the primary driver.

QUESTIONS: 31. Which of the following refers to why and how people eat, which foods they eat, and with whom they eat?
DESCRIPTION A: Study of the makeup of food.
DESCRIPTION B: Social and cultural patterns of consumption.

QUESTIONS: 32. Without this factor, people would only be able to eat food grown and processed locally.
DESCRIPTION A: Helps process but doesn't move it across distances.
DESCRIPTION B: Supports trade but isn't the physical means.

QUESTIONS: 33. Technology in the food industry primarily relates to which of th efollowing?
DESCRIPTION B: This is food styling or culinary art.
DESCRIPTION C: Applies to the entire supply chain.

QUESTIONS: 34. Which kitchen layout is considered the most efficient by many experts?
DESCRIPTION A: Provides the best compact work triangle.
DESCRIPTION B: Efficient for one but creates traffic jams.
DESCRIPTION C: Least efficient due to lack of triangle.

QUESTIONS: 35. What is formed by the imaginary lines connecting the refrigerator, sink, and range?
DESCRIPTION B: Not a standard kitchen design term.
DESCRIPTION C: Not a standard kitchen design term.
DECRIPTION D: Principle ensuring efficient distance between centers.

QUESTIONS: 36. Which type of kitchen is frequently used in apartments but often lacks sufficient counter space?
DESCRIPTION B: Common in tiny apartments to save space.
DECRIPTION D: Requires three walls, rare in tiny units.

QUESTIONS: 37. Which kitchen innovation from 1834 helped reduce the task of moving heavy iron cookware?
DESCRIPTION A: Localized heat and reduced labor of moving pots.

QUESTIONS: 38. Which tool is specifically used for removing a thin outer layer from fruits and vegetables?
DESCRIPTION A: Specifically designed for thin skin removal.
DECRIPTION D: Can peel, but isn't specifically for thin layers.

QUESTIONS: 39. What is the primary purpose of a dishwasher in the kitchen?
B: To efficiently clean and sanitize dishes
DESCRIPTION A: This is the role of a cabinet.
DESCRIPTION B: Primary goal is hygiene and labor-saving.
DESCRIPTION C: Efficiency is a benefit, not the primary goal.
DECRIPTION D: This is a secondary drying cycle.

QUESTIONS: 40. What is the difference between cleaning and sanitizing?
D: Cleaning removes visible dirt; sanitizing removes harmful microorganisms.
DESCRIPTION A: Cleaning only moves or removes dirt.
DESCRIPTION C: Soap is for cleaning; sanitizing uses bleach/heat.
DECRIPTION D: Defines the two distinct steps in safety.

QUESTIONS: 41. What is the safest way to extinguish a grease fire?
A: Pour salt or baking soda over the flames.

QUESTIONS: 42. When using a sharp knife, in which direction should you cut?
DESCRIPTION C: Standard safety rule to prevent injury.

QUESTIONS: 43. Which of the following is an unsafe practice in the kitchen?
B: Using electric appliances with wet hands.

QUESTIONS: 44. What temperature of water is typically used to sanitize surfaces?
45. To retain the maximum amount of nutrients, color, and flavor, how should vegetables be cooked?
A: Boiled in a large amount of water.
C: Cooked in as little water as possible.
DESCRIPTION B: Destroys vitamins and adds excessive fat.
DECRIPTION D: Covering is usually better for steam.

QUESTIONS: 46. Why do commercially frozen vegetables require shorter cooking times than fresh ones?
B: They are softer because of the ice.
C: They are cut into smaller pieces.
DESCRIPTION A: Blanching stops enzymes and softens them.
DESCRIPTION B: Ice doesn't make them "soft" in a cooked sense.
DECRIPTION D: Freezing slows chemistry; doesn't cook them.

QUESTIONS: 47. What is the best storage place for most fresh vegetables to keep them cold and moist?
C: A sealed plastic bag in the sun.
DESCRIPTION C: Causes rapid rot and bacterial growth.
DECRIPTION D: Provides a cold, humid environment needed.

QUESTIONS: 48. To prevent fruits like apples and pears from browning after cutting, what should you do?
D: Leave them in the open air.
DESCRIPTION B: Ruins texture and only slows browning.

QUESTIONS: 49. Which cooking method is best suited for tender cuts of meat like loin and ribs?
DESCRIPTION A: Tender cuts cook quickly without needing moisture.
DESCRIPTION B: Used for tough cuts to break down connective tissue.
DECRIPTION D: Reserved for tougher cuts like shank.

QUESTIONS: 50. What is "cured" meat?
A: Meat that has been fully cooked.
B: Meat is sold exactly as it comes from the animal.
DESCRIPTION A: Some cured meats still need cooking.
DESCRIPTION C: Treated with salt/nitrates to prevent spoilage.

QUESTIONS: 51. During a "red tide," which of the following is unsafe to eat?
DESCRIPTION A: Generally safe if toxin is removed from organs.
DESCRIPTION B: They ingest and concentrate toxic algae.

QUESTIONS: 52. Which part of the fish must be removed before cooking during a red tide event?
D: The gills, viscera, and internal organs.
DECRIPTION D: Areas where toxic algae are trapped and processed.

QUESTIONS: 53. Variety meats include which of the following?
54. What is the difference between an appetizer salad and a main course salad?
B: The appetizer salad contains more meat.
C: The main course salad is usually larger in portion.
DESCRIPTION A: Appetizers are small to stimulate appetite.
DESCRIPTION B: Main course salads usually contain the meat.
DESCRIPTION C: Substantial enough for a full meal.
DECRIPTION D: Differ in size and nutrient density.

QUESTIONS: 55. Why should salads containing milk or eggs be refrigerated?
C: To make them easier to serve.
D: To prevent the growth of bacteria.
DECRIPTION D: Prevents growth of bacteria in high-risk foods.

QUESTIONS: 56. Which salad dressing is a combination of chili sauce, sweet pickle relish, and hard-cooked eggs?
DESCRIPTION A: Usually uses mayonnaise as a base.
DECRIPTION D: Simple mix of oil and vinegar.

QUESTIONS: 57. What is the best way to handle salad greens to avoid bruising them?
A: Cut them with a sharp knife.
B: Chop them in a food processor.
DESCRIPTION A: Metal knives can cause browning at the cut edge.

QUESTIONS: 58. Which form of food typically conserves the most nutrients?
59. What is "Mise en place" in food preparation?
60. Which of these is an immune-booster beverage mentioned in the module?
DESCRIPTION A: Not classified as such in this context.
DESCRIPTION B: High sugar suppresses the immune system.

QUESTIONS: 61. Which macronutrient is the body's primary and most preferred source of energy?
DESCRIPTION B: The main job is building and repairing tissues.
DECRIPTION D: These are micronutrients with no calories.

QUESTIONS: 62. In the "Pinggang Pinoy" concept, what is the primary role of "Grow Foods" like fish and meat?
63. Which mineral is the core component of hemoglobin, which carries oxygen in the blood?
64. What is the temperature "Danger Zone" where foodborne bacteria multiply most rapidly?
65. "Cross-contamination" in food safety is best described by which scenario?
B: Storing rice in a sealed container.
C: Touching raw meat then touching salad without washing hands.

QUESTIONS: 66. Why is dietary fiber important in the human diet?
67. Which vitamin can be synthesized by the body through skin exposure to sunlight?
DECRIPTION D: Produced via skin exposure to UV.

QUESTIONS: 68. Kwashiorkor is a form of malnutrition characterized by a swollen belly. What is missing?
DESCRIPTION B: Lack of protein causes fluid leaks.

QUESTIONS: 69. Which method is classified as "Dry Heat" cooking?
70. Food Fortification in the Philippines (e.g., Vitamin A in flour) aims to:
C: Address micronutrient deficiencies in the population.

QUESTIONS: 71. Which of the following is an example of a "Glow Food"?
72. How much energy does 1 gram of fat provide?
73. A BMI (Body Mass Indez) of 32 falls under which category?
74. Which vitamin is NOT fat-soluble?
75. What mineral is added to salt to prevent Goiter?
76. In the "FIFO" storage system, what does the acronym stand for?
DECRIPTION D: Would lead to older food rotting.

QUESTIONS: 77. Which nutrient is essential for blood clotting?
78. Which cooking method is best for preserving the most nutrients in vegetables?
79. What is the role of "Electrolytes" like Sodium and Potassium?
80. Which of these is a "Complete Protein" source?
81. Which practice is considered "Food Sanitation"?
A: Keeping the kitchen surfaces clean and germ-free.

QUESTIONS: 82. Why should we avoid "Skipping Breakfast"?
C: It provides the fuel needed for morning activities.

QUESTIONS: 83. Which mineral helps prevent dental cavities?
84. What does "Perishable" food mean?
B: Food that spoils quickly if not refrigerated.

QUESTIONS: 85. What is "Food Literacy"?
A: The ability to read a menu.
B: Knowing how to write a cookbook.
C: Knowledge and skills to make healthy food choices.

QUESTIONS: 86. Which vitamin is essential for a healthy pregnancy to prevent neural tube defects?
87. Which of the following is the best example of "Food Preservation" by lowering the water activity?
88. In the "Philippine Dietary Reference Intakes" (PDRI), what does the "RNI" stand for?
98. When a person eats too much salty food (high sodium), what is the most likely immediate effect on the body?
A: The person will feel very energetic.
B: The person will lose weight immediately.
C: The body will retain water, potentially increasing blood pressure.
D: The person’s bones will get stronger.

QUESTIONS: 90. Which of the following is a symptom of Iodine Deficiency Disorder (IDD) aside from goiter?
DESCRIPTION A: Iodine is crucial for brain development.
